elements.content: Uranium trioxide UO3 reacts with cucurbit[5]uril (CB5) under hydrothermal conditions and in the presence of perrhenic acid to give [UO2(CB5)](ReO4)2·2H2O (1) in which the uranyl ion is encompassed by the five oxygen atoms of one CB5 portal, giving an open molecular capsule. When uranyl nitrate is reacted with CB5 in the presence of alkali metal salts, mixed capsules, capped by one uranyl ion at one portal and K+ or Cs+ at the other, are obtained either as discrete dicationic species in [UO2(CB5)K(NO3)][UO2(NO3)4]·H2O (2) or as part of pentanuclear dicationic assemblages in {[UO2(CB5)Cs(NO3)]2[UO2(NO3)4]}[UO2(NO3)4]·2H2O (3). Finally, the reaction of UO3 with CB5 in the presence of KOH or CsOH, with addition of formic acid, resulted in the formation of the compounds [K2(CB5)(H2O)][(UO2)2(HCOO)(OH)4]2·6H2O (4) and [Cs2(CB5)(H2O)2][(UO2)2(HCOO)(OH)4]2·3H2O (5). In these cases, the uranyl ions are separated from CB5 to form a uranyl/formate/hydroxide two-dimensional assemblage; CB5 capsules capped by K+ or Cs+ at both portals are bound to successive uranyl-organic layers to give a three-dimensional framework of unprecedented architecture.

Finally, the reaction of UO3 with CB5 in the presence of KOH or CsOH, with addition of formic acid, resulted in the formation of the compounds [K2(CB5)(H2O)][(UO2)2(HCOO)(OH)4]2⋅6H2O (4) and [Cs2(CB5)(H2O)2][(UO2)2(HCOO)(OH)4]2⋅3H2O (5). In these cases, the uranyl ions are separated from CB5 to form a uranyl/formate/hydroxide two-dimensional assemblage; CB5 capsules capped by K+ or Cs+ at both portals are bound to successive uranyl-organic layers to give a three-dimensional framework of unprecedented architecture.

elements.content: The first examples of uranyl complexes with cucurbit[5]uril are reported. The perfect size match results in the bonding of uranyl to the five oxygen donors of one portal, giving an open capsule. In the presence of alkali metal ions, heterometallic closed capsules are obtained, whereas the addition of formic acid gives three-dimensional frameworks comprising uranyl-organic layers connected by alkali metal ion/CB5 capsules located in between.
elements.clean_text: The first examples of uranyl complexes with cucurbit[5]uril are reported. The perfect size match results in the bonding of uranyl to the five oxygen donors of one portal, giving an open capsule. In the presence of alkali metal ions, heterometallic closed capsules are obtained, whereas the addition of formic acid gives three-dimensional frameworks comprising uranyl-organic layers connected by alkali metal ion/CB5 capsules located in between.

elements.content: The metal ion-complexing properties of cucurbiturils have been much investigated in the past years and, in particular, the complexes with alkali, alkaline-earth, and lanthanide ions have been thoroughly explored. Concerning 5f element ions, although a thorium(IV) complex has been described, the first examples of uranyl complexes with cucurbit[n]urils (n = 6, 7, 8), with direct U−O(carbonyl) bonds, were reported only very recently. When varying the experimental conditions, different uranyl/cucurbituril assemblages could be obtained, from a molecular, three-decker dinuclear species to one- and two-dimensional frameworks (the latter with additional bridging provided by sulfate ions). However, in several cases, the macrocycle is only a second sphere ligand, hydrogen bonded to the uranyl aquo ligands. The cucurbiturils used in the previous study, with 6, 7, or 8 glycoluril units, display on either portal an array of oxygen donors which is too large to be suitable for the bonding of a unique uranyl ion perpendicular to the opening. In this respect, cucurbit[5]uril (CB5, Scheme ) appeared possibly much better adapted. CB5 is known to form capsules when capped by alkali metal or lanthanide ions, and a similar complex could be expected to form with uranyl. An analogous situation arises with calixarenes, with calix[5]arene complexing the uranyl ion through its five oxygen atoms while calix[6]arene only gives an “external” complex. However, in this case, the greater flexibility of the macrocycle enables “internal” complexation to be also achieved with larger calixarenes such as calix[7]arene. The complexes formed between uranyl ions and CB5 under hydrothermal conditions were thus investigated, with different added species leading to various architectures, among which are the first uranyl-capped cucurbiturils.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The metal ion-complexing properties of cucurbiturils have been much investigated in the past years and, in particular, the complexes with alkali, alkaline-earth, and lanthanide ions have been thoroughly explored. Concerning 5f element ions, although a thorium(IV) complex has been described, the first examples of uranyl complexes with cucurbit[n]urils (n = 6, 7, 8), with direct U-O(carbonyl) bonds, were reported only very recently. When varying the experimental conditions, different uranyl/cucurbituril assemblages could be obtained, from a molecular, three-decker dinuclear species to one- and two-dimensional frameworks (the latter with additional bridging provided by sulfate ions). However, in several cases, the macrocycle is only a second sphere ligand, hydrogen bonded to the uranyl aquo ligands. The cucurbiturils used in the previous study, with 6, 7, or 8 glycoluril units, display on either portal an array of oxygen donors which is too large to be suitable for the bonding of a unique uranyl ion perpendicular to the opening. In this respect, cucurbit[5]uril (CB5, Scheme ) appeared possibly much better adapted. CB5 is known to form capsules when capped by alkali metal or lanthanide ions, and a similar complex could be expected to form with uranyl. An analogous situation arises with calixarenes, with calix[5]arene complexing the uranyl ion through its five oxygen atoms while calix[6]arene only gives an "external" complex. However, in this case, the greater flexibility of the macrocycle enables "internal" complexation to be also achieved with larger calixarenes such as calix[7]arene. The complexes formed between uranyl ions and CB5 under hydrothermal conditions were thus investigated, with different added species leading to various architectures, among which are the first uranyl-capped cucurbiturils.

elements.content:
Caution! Because uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection.

UO2(NO3)2·6H2O was purchased from Prolabo and UO3 was provided by the CEA, perrhenic acid (76.5% solution in water) was purchased from Acros and cucurbit[5]uril hydrate from Aldrich. The water content in the latter compound was estimated at about 12 water molecules per cucurbituril molecule, according to the analyses provided by the seller. Elemental analyses were performed by Analytische Laboratorien GmbH at Lindlar, Germany. The reaction conditions used often result in the formation of insoluble powders and only in some out of many attempts with varying reactants and concentrations was it possible to get single crystals suitable for structure determination (for some comments about the choice of the reactants, and particularly the use of perrhenic acid, see the Results and Discussion section).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

 Caution! Because uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection. 

UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O was purchased from Prolabo and UO3 was provided by the CEA, perrhenic acid (76.5% solution in water) was purchased from Acros and cucurbit[5]uril hydrate from Aldrich. The water content in the latter compound was estimated at about 12 water molecules per cucurbituril molecule, according to the analyses provided by the seller. Elemental analyses were performed by Analytische Laboratorien GmbH at Lindlar, Germany. The reaction conditions used often result in the formation of insoluble powders and only in some out of many attempts with varying reactants and concentrations was it possible to get single crystals suitable for structure determination (for some comments about the choice of the reactants, and particularly the use of perrhenic acid, see the Results and Discussion section).

elements.content: CB5·12H2O (10 mg, 0.010 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO3 (29 mg, 0.101 mmol), excess HReO4 (100 mg, 0.398 mmol), and demineralized water (1.4 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 1 appeared within 2 days. The product was recovered after filtration and washed with water (8 mg, 49% yield based on CB5). Anal. Calcd for C30H34N20O22Re2U: C, 22.01; H, 2.09; N, 17.11. Found: C, 23.49; H, 2.81; N, 17.87%.

elements.content: The data were collected at 100(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protecting “Paratone-N” oil (Hampton Research) coating. The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames, then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans giving complete data sets up to θ = 25.7° and a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97, expanded by subsequent Fourier-difference synthesis, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. All hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom. Special details are as follows:
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The data were collected at 100(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protecting "Paratone-N" oil (Hampton Research) coating. The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames, then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans giving complete data sets up to θ = 25.7° and a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97, expanded by subsequent Fourier-difference synthesis, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. All hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom. Special details are as follows:

elements.content: Although presenting an approximate mirror plane, the structure could not be solved in a higher symmetry space group, and ADDSYM (PLATON) does not detect any missing symmetry element. Restraints on bond lengths and/or displacement parameters were applied for some badly behaving atoms, particularly in the perrhenate counter-ions. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were not found. Some voids in the lattice likely indicate the presence of other, unresolved water solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Compound 1

Although presenting an approximate mirror plane, the structure could not be solved in a higher symmetry space group, and ADDSYM (PLATON) does not detect any missing symmetry element. Restraints on bond lengths and/or displacement parameters were applied for some badly behaving atoms, particularly in the perrhenate counter-ions. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were not found. Some voids in the lattice likely indicate the presence of other, unresolved water solvent molecules.

elements.content: The nitrate ion bound to K1 is disordered over two positions which were refined with occupancy parameters constrained to sum to unity, whereas the nitrate ions containing N25 and N26 were given occupancy parameters of 0.5 to account for their disorder around a binary axis, corresponding to the disorder affecting the oxo atom O23. Restraints on bond lengths and/or displacement parameters were applied for several of the very badly resolved nitrate ions (those containing N21B, N23, N25, and N26). Several intermolecular short contacts involving the disordered atoms are likely due to the low resolution of these parts. The presence of further, unresolved disorder, is indicated by the location of the highest residual electron density peaks close to the disordered parts. The hydrogen atoms of the water molecule were not found.
elements.clean_text:
Compound 2

The nitrate ion bound to K1 is disordered over two positions which were refined with occupancy parameters constrained to sum to unity, whereas the nitrate ions containing N25 and N26 were given occupancy parameters of 0.5 to account for their disorder around a binary axis, corresponding to the disorder affecting the oxo atom O23. Restraints on bond lengths and/or displacement parameters were applied for several of the very badly resolved nitrate ions (those containing N21B, N23, N25, and N26). Several intermolecular short contacts involving the disordered atoms are likely due to the low resolution of these parts. The presence of further, unresolved disorder, is indicated by the location of the highest residual electron density peaks close to the disordered parts. The hydrogen atoms of the water molecule were not found.

elements.content: As in compound 2, the nitrate ions containing N25 and N26 were given occupancy parameters of 0.5 to account for their disorder around a binary axis, corresponding to the disorder affecting the oxo atom O23. The nitrate ion containing N25 was extremely badly resolved and unstable, and it had to be fixed in a position which remains quite uncertain, with a common displacement factor for all atoms. Restraints on bond lengths and/or displacement parameters were applied for the nitrate ions containing N21 and N26. Some short intermolecular contacts involving the disordered and badly resolved nitrate ion are likely due to the imperfect description of this moiety. The hydrogen atoms of the water molecule were not found.
elements.clean_text:
Compound 3

As in compound 2, the nitrate ions containing N25 and N26 were given occupancy parameters of 0.5 to account for their disorder around a binary axis, corresponding to the disorder affecting the oxo atom O23. The nitrate ion containing N25 was extremely badly resolved and unstable, and it had to be fixed in a position which remains quite uncertain, with a common displacement factor for all atoms. Restraints on bond lengths and/or displacement parameters were applied for the nitrate ions containing N21 and N26. Some short intermolecular contacts involving the disordered and badly resolved nitrate ion are likely due to the imperfect description of this moiety. The hydrogen atoms of the water molecule were not found.

elements.content: The water molecule bound to potassium was found to be disordered over two positions coordinated to either K1 or K2 and located on a mirror plane, which have been refined with occupancy parameters constrained to sum to 0.5. Restraints on displacement parameters were applied for some badly behaving atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the hydroxide groups O7−O12 were found on a Fourier-difference map but not those of the water molecules.

elements.content:
Crystal data and structure refinement parameters are given in Table and selected bond lengths and angles in Table . The molecular plots were drawn with SHELXTL and Balls & Sticks.

Results and Discussion

In the course of previous work on uranyl/cucurbituril complexes, it had been noticed that a problem commonly encountered was the formation of insoluble powders and/or the small quantity of crystals, which often prevents further characterization of the complexes. This is also true in the present case, and the small quantities of CB5 used in the syntheses contribute to make things worse. However, it was possible to get single crystals suitable for diffraction measurements in several experiments. Reaction of uranyl nitrate with CB5 in the absence of other reactants did not give any suitable crystalline material. In the presence of alkali metal salts (KCl or CsNO3 in the successful experiments), added so as to promote CB5 dissolution, the heterometallic uranyl/alkali ion/CB5 capsules 2 and 3 were obtained, in which CB5 is capped by different cations at its two portals. When uranyl nitrate was replaced by uranium trioxide, with formic acid added to acidify the solution (and promote uranium trioxide and cucurbituril dissolution) in the presence of KOH or CsOH, alkali metal ion capsules were formed (4 and 5), the uranyl ions being separated from CB5 to form a uranyl formate two-dimensional subunit. No single crystal was obtained in the presence of sulfuric acid, but previous work has shown that the presence of sulfate ions results in the formation of uranyl sulfate polynuclear subunits, which permits the obtainment of two-dimensional frameworks, as observed with CB7 and CB8, but is unfavorable to uranyl bonding by the five oxygen atoms of CB5, whereas the use of HCl results in the formation of second sphere complexes. It thus appeared desirable to find an acid providing a quite weakly coordinating anion, and perrhenic acid HReO4 was found to be well adapted since it permitted to isolate the mononuclear, uranyl-capped complex 1 which, being the simplest in the present series, will be described first. A common problem with all these structures is the presence of disorder, which affects particularly the counterions and could not always be properly modeled; the connectivity of the CB5 complexes, which is the essential point here, is nonetheless unambiguous.

In the course of previous work on uranyl/cucurbituril complexes, it had been noticed that a problem commonly encountered was the formation of insoluble powders and/or the small quantity of crystals, which often prevents further characterization of the complexes. The asymmetric unit in [UO2(CB5)](ReO4)2·2H2O (1) comprises one uranyl ion encompassed by one CB5 molecule to give a dicationic complex, two perrhenate counterions and two water solvent molecules (Figure ). The uranyl ion is bound to the five carbonyl groups of one CB5 portal, with an average U−O bond length of 2.38(2) Å, in agreement with the average value of 2.41(7) Å in the previous uranyl/cucurbituril complexes and with the mean value of 2.36(4) Å in the structures involving urea derivatives reported in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, Version 5.29). The limited bond length range in 1 [2.342(10)−2.410(9) Å] is indicative of the quite perfect match between the cation and the O5 coordination site. The five donor atoms define a plane with a root mean squares (rms) deviation of 0.008 Å, with the uranium atom displaced by 0.061(4) Å only, toward the outside of the macrocycle. The uranyl ion is perpendicular to the O5 plane, with an angle of 1.2° with the normal to the plane and the uranium environment is thus a quite regular pentagonal bipyramid. This complex is reminiscent of the uranyl complex with the 4-fold deprotonated form of p-tert-butylcalix[5]arene, in which the uranyl ion is similarly located with respect to the phenoxide/phenolic O5 plane. However, the U−O(calixarene) bond lengths in the latter case span a much wider range, 2.254(7)−2.836(8) Å [average value 2.4(2) Å], which is due to the presence of one phenolic group and may also indicate that the calixarene O5 site is slightly too large for the uranyl ion. The O···O distances between adjacent atoms in the planar site are in the range 2.52(1)−3.07(1) Å in the calixarene [mean value 2.86(19) Å, the shortest distance corresponds to hydrogen bonded oxygen atoms] and in the range 2.766(18)−2.859(14) Å in the cucurbituril [mean value 2.80(3) Å], indicating nearly identical average cavity sizes. This size matches perfectly the requirements of uranyl when complexed by carbonyl groups, whereas it seems to be slightly too large for phenoxide complexation (typical U−O bond length about 2.25 Å). However, it must be noted that CB5 undergoes some deformation to adapt to the uranyl cation, since the O···O distances in the uncomplexed portal are much larger, in the range 3.20(2)−3.45(2) Å [mean value 3.29(9) Å], in agreement with the values in CB5 tetrahydrate, 3.18−3.60 Å [mean value 3.31(14) Å]. In the uranyl complexes with CB6, CB7 and CB8, only “external” complexation is observed, with each cation bound to one or two macrocycles in monodentate fashion. The uranyl ion being generally able to accept six equatorial donors at most, only in the case of CB6 could it be possible to observe “internal” complexation with all oxygen atoms involved, but, as a matter of fact, CB6 is unable to undergo sufficient distortion to allow this (six-coordination of uranyl is only observed with small-bite chelating ligands). On the other hand, CB7 or CB8 could in principle encompass one uranyl ion perpendicular to their mean plane and bound to only some of the oxygen atoms, the coordination sphere being completed by small additional ligands such as water molecules, but this has not been observed hitherto. A comparable situation is encountered in the calixarene family since p-tert-butylcalix[6]arene only gives dinuclear, dimeric “external” complexes, and also in the homooxacalixarene series, with p-tert-butyldihomooxacalix[5]arene, comparable in size to calix[6]arene, giving a mononuclear, “external” sandwich complex, whereas the smaller p-R-hexahomotrioxacalix[3]arene, p-tert-butyldihomooxacalix[4]arene and p-R-tetrahomodioxacalix[4]arene display “internal” complexation similar to that observed here. However, the flexibility of calixarenes and homooxacalixarenes enables “internal” complexation of up to four uranyl ions in larger members of the series. Such versatility is hardly to be expected in the cucurbituril family.

elements.content: Top: View of the dicationic uranyl complex in 1. Displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 10% probability level. Hydrogen atoms are omitted. Bottom: View of the packing down the c axis. Solvent molecules and hydrogen atoms are omitted. The presence of CH···O interactions is indicated by arrows.

elements.content: The uncomplexed portal of CB5 in complex 1 plays a significant role in the crystal packing arrangement since intermolecular CH···O hydrogen bonding interactions involving either CH or CH2 groups are formed between neighboring molecules, with H···O distances in the range 2.14−2.77 Å. Tetramers are thus assembled around the 4-fold rotoinversion axis, with no such interactions being present between neighboring tetramers (Figure ). CH···O hydrogen bonds, although weak, are frequent in cucurbituril structures in which they likely display a structure-directing influence. Similar interactions, either intra- or intermolecular, have been encountered in the previous examples of uranyl complexes.

elements.content: Compounds [UO2(CB5)K(NO3)][UO2(NO3)4]·H2O (2) and {[UO2(CB5)Cs(NO3)]2[UO2(NO3)4]}[UO2(NO3)4]·2H2O (3), although best represented by quite different formulas because of the differing connectivity of K+ and Cs+, are closely related and crystallize in the same space group with nearly identical unit cell parameters. Both present a capsular unit comprising a uranyl/CB5 complex similar to that encountered in 1, capped by the alkali metal ion at its second portal (Figures and ). Uranyl complexation in both compounds is strictly identical to that in 1, with average U−O(CB5) bond lengths of 2.401(17) and 2.40(2) Å in 2 and 3, respectively, and the uranium atom displaced toward the outside by 0.077(7) and 0.085(8) Å from the mean O5 plane (rms deviations 0.02 and 0.03 Å). The alkali metal atoms are bound to the five carbonyl groups, with average K−O(CB5) and Cs−O(CB5) bond lengths of 2.80(6) and 2.97(4) Å. A capsule comprising a CB5 molecule capped by two potassium ions is already known, as well as a monocapped CB5, in which the average K−O bond lengths are 2.71(4) and 2.73(3) Å, respectively. In these cases, the cation is very close to the O5 plane, whereas it is displaced by 0.872(11) Å in 2, its coordination sphere being completed by a disordered nitrate ion. Only two other examples of cesium-complexed cucurbituril structures have been reported, both involving CB6. One is quite different from the present case since only four oxygen atoms are coordinated at each portal, with an average Cs−O bond length of 3.22(12) Å, while the six donors of only one portal are bound in the second example, with a large range of Cs−O bond lengths giving an average value of 3.39(19) Å. The bond lengths in the present compounds appear to be larger and smaller than those in these previous examples, for K+ and Cs+ respectively, but they are, however, compatible with them when the 3 × esd confidence intervals on individual experimental values (which are very large in the present, disordered structures) are considered. In compound 2, two isolated [UO2(NO3)4]2− halves are present as counter-ions, while a terminal nitrate oxygen atom of one of these units is bound to cesium in 3, resulting in eight-coordination. Centrosymmetric, dicationic pentanuclear dimers are thus formed in 3, in which two capsules are loosely connected by a uranyl tetranitrate bridge. The O···O distances in the uranyl-complexed portals are in the range 2.80(3)−2.85(3) Å [mean value 2.820(18) Å] in 2 and 2.79(3)−2.86(3) Å [mean value 2.82(3) Å] in 3, showing no difference with complex 1. The alkali metal ion-complexed portals may be a little smaller than in 1 and in CB5 tetrahydrate, albeit not quite significantly, with O···O distances in the range 2.99(3)−3.22(3) Å [mean value 3.13(8) Å] for K+ and 3.08(3)−3.28(3) Å [mean value 3.20(7) Å] for Cs+. The average O···O distances in the potassium/CB5 complexes previously reported are identical to the present ones, at 3.11(5) and 3.18(4) Å. The uranyl tetranitrate dianion is a relatively rare motif since only four cases are reported in the CSD. In all of them, as for the two anions in 2 and one in 3, two nitrates are chelating and the other two monodentate; the average U−O(chelating) and U−O(monodentate) bond lengths are 2.54(3) and 2.46(5) Å in 2 and 3, respectively, to be compared to 2.517(18) and 2.438(13) Å from the CSD. The second anion in 3 may possibly display seven-coordination of the uranyl ion, but the very badly resolved disorder affecting this part of the structure (as well as, to a lesser degree, the other anions as well; see Experimental Section) prevents any clear-cut conclusion to be drawn.
elements.clean_text: Compounds [UO2(CB5)K(NO3)][UO2(NO3)4]⋅H2O (2) and {[UO2(CB5)Cs(NO3)]2[UO2(NO3)4]}[UO2(NO3)4]⋅2H2O (3), although best represented by quite different formulas because of the differing connectivity of K+ and Cs+, are closely related and crystallize in the same space group with nearly identical unit cell parameters. Both present a capsular unit comprising a uranyl/CB5 complex similar to that encountered in 1, capped by the alkali metal ion at its second portal (Figures  and ). Uranyl complexation in both compounds is strictly identical to that in 1, with average U-O(CB5) bond lengths of 2.401(17) and 2.40(2) Å in 2 and 3, respectively, and the uranium atom displaced toward the outside by 0.077(7) and 0.085(8) Å from the mean O5 plane (rms deviations 0.02 and 0.03 Å). The alkali metal atoms are bound to the five carbonyl groups, with average K-O(CB5) and Cs-O(CB5) bond lengths of 2.80(6) and 2.97(4) Å. A capsule comprising a CB5 molecule capped by two potassium ions is already known, as well as a monocapped CB5, in which the average K-O bond lengths are 2.71(4) and 2.73(3) Å, respectively. In these cases, the cation is very close to the O5 plane, whereas it is displaced by 0.872(11) Å in 2, its coordination sphere being completed by a disordered nitrate ion. Only two other examples of cesium-complexed cucurbituril structures have been reported, both involving CB6. One is quite different from the present case since only four oxygen atoms are coordinated at each portal, with an average Cs-O bond length of 3.22(12) Å, while the six donors of only one portal are bound in the second example, with a large range of Cs-O bond lengths giving an average value of 3.39(19) Å. The bond lengths in the present compounds appear to be larger and smaller than those in these previous examples, for K+ and Cs+ respectively, but they are, however, compatible with them when the 3 × esd confidence intervals on individual experimental values (which are very large in the present, disordered structures) are considered. In compound 2, two isolated [UO2(NO3)4]2- halves are present as counter-ions, while a terminal nitrate oxygen atom of one of these units is bound to cesium in 3, resulting in eight-coordination. Centrosymmetric, dicationic pentanuclear dimers are thus formed in 3, in which two capsules are loosely connected by a uranyl tetranitrate bridge. The O⋅⋅⋅O distances in the uranyl-complexed portals are in the range 2.80(3)-2.85(3) Å [mean value 2.820(18) Å] in 2 and 2.79(3)-2.86(3) Å [mean value 2.82(3) Å] in 3, showing no difference with complex 1. The alkali metal ion-complexed portals may be a little smaller than in 1 and in CB5 tetrahydrate, albeit not quite significantly, with O⋅⋅⋅O distances in the range 2.99(3)-3.22(3) Å [mean value 3.13(8) Å] for K+ and 3.08(3)-3.28(3) Å [mean value 3.20(7) Å] for Cs+. The average O⋅⋅⋅O distances in the potassium/CB5 complexes previously reported are identical to the present ones, at 3.11(5) and 3.18(4) Å. The uranyl tetranitrate dianion is a relatively rare motif since only four cases are reported in the CSD. In all of them, as for the two anions in 2 and one in 3, two nitrates are chelating and the other two monodentate; the average U-O(chelating) and U-O(monodentate) bond lengths are 2.54(3) and 2.46(5) Å in 2 and 3, respectively, to be compared to 2.517(18) and 2.438(13) Å from the CSD. The second anion in 3 may possibly display seven-coordination of the uranyl ion, but the very badly resolved disorder affecting this part of the structure (as well as, to a lesser degree, the other anions as well; see Experimental Section) prevents any clear-cut conclusion to be drawn.

elements.content: When formic acid is added to the reaction medium containing both uranyl and alkali metal ions (either K+ or Cs+), the two complexes [K2(CB5)(H2O)][(UO2)2(HCOO)(OH)4]2·6H2O (4) and [Cs2(CB5)(H2O)2][(UO2)2(HCOO)(OH)4]2·3H2O (5) are formed. Although not isomorphous, these two complexes are very close to one another, as can be seen in Figures and . The strong affinity of formic acid for uranyl ions results in the formation of a uranyl/formate/hydroxide framework, both coordination sites of CB5 being occupied by alkali metal ions. In both compounds, the asymmetric unit contains two uranyl ions, one formate and two hydroxide ions (O8, O11) in general position and two alkali metal cations, one CB5 molecule and four hydroxide ions (O7, O9, O10, O12) located on or around a mirror plane. Each uranyl ion is bound to one formate anion in monodentate fashion and to four bridging hydroxide ions, which gives a pentagonal bipyramidal uranium environment. The formate ion is bridging the two independent uranium atoms U1 and U2 in the anti/anti mode, with an average bond length of 2.429(9) Å (both compounds included) to be compared to the average value of 2.39(5) Å for similar examples in the CSD. The mean U−O(hydroxide) bond length is 2.36(3) Å and the average U−O(hydroxide)−U angle is 111(2)°, in agreement with the average values of 2.33(2) Å and 112(2)° for the double μ2-OH linkages reported in the CSD. The two-dimensional uranyl-organic framework thus formed is represented in Figure for compound 4. Five polymeric structures of uranyl formate are reported in the CSD, and two more were recently described, among which is a nanotubular assemblage, but none is similar to the polyanionic grid observed in 4 and 5. [UO2(OH)2]∞ zigzag chains run along the b axis, and they are linked to one another along the c axis by formate bridges to give [(UO2)2(HCOO)(OH)4]∞ sheets parallel to the bc plane. Two kinds of rings are thus defined, small ones corresponding to four metal atoms, two formate and two hydroxide bridges, and larger ones comprising eight metal atoms, two formate and six hydroxide bridges. The stacking of the sheets gives rise to approximately cylindrical channels associated to the largest rings, running down the a axis, with an average diameter of about 8.6 Å (5.6 Å after correction for the oxygen van der Waals radius). This assemblage is markedly different from that in [UO2(HCOO)(OH)(H2O)]∞, in which each uranium atom is bound to two formate and two hydroxide bridging ligands and to a water molecule. The alkali metal ions in 4 and 5 are bound to the five oxygen atoms of the portals, with average K−O and Cs−O bond lengths of 2.78(7) and 2.95(7) Å, respectively, in agreement with their counterparts in 2 and 3. The alkali metal ions/CB5 capsules are connected to the planar uranyl-organic frameworks through bonding of each alkali metal ion to two uranyl oxo groups and one hydroxide ion. The former are frequent in uranyl structural chemistry as a result of the Lewis basicity of the oxo groups. The average K−O(oxo) and Cs−O(oxo) bond lengths are 3.11(9) and 3.174(4) Å in 4 and 5, respectively. The former is in the range observed for such bonds in a series of homooxacalixarene complexes, 2.658(6)−3.230(6) Å [mean value 2.8(2) Å] and the latter matches perfectly the average value in these complexes, 3.17(7) Å. The average bond lengths with the hydroxide ions are 2.91(7) Å for K+ and 3.20(7) Å for Cs+, in perfect agreement with the average values of 2.93(11) and 3.25(19) Å for comparable bonds with bridging hydroxides in the CSD. The alkali metal ion coordination sphere is completed either by one disordered water molecule located in the CB5 cavity for potassium or by two water molecules located outside for one of the cesium ions, with average K−O(aquo) and Cs−O(aquo) bond lengths of 3.12(3) and 3.71(8) Å which, if they are in the ranges for such bonds in the CSD, 2.26−3.40 Å [mean value 2.82 (17) Å] for K+ and 3.01−3.80 Å [mean value 3.28(17) Å] for Cs+, are however large and likely indicate rather loose interactions. Hydrogen bonding between hydroxide ions and carbonyl groups of CB5 also contribute to the connection of the two complex subunits (Table ). The CB5 capsules are arranged in planes alternating with the uranyl formate frameworks along the a axis (Figure ), with the former at the center of the channels when projected onto the bc plane (Figure ). The two alkali metal ions in each capsule are bound to different uranyl-organic sheets, the capsules being tilted with respect to the a axis so that they are bound to diametrically opposite points in the channels when viewed down a. Although the overall, three-dimensional arrangements in 4 and 5 are very close to one another, there are some differences due to the distinct crystal systems and space groups (it may be noted that the unit cell axes parameters obviously present some relation, with one of them being doubled in 5). In compound 4, two CB5 molecules are comprised in the unit cell and they are related to one another by the inversion center at (1/2 1/2 1/2) [or the binary screw axis (1/2 y 1/2)]. Viewed down b, all the capsules thus display the same orientation. In compound 5, the unit cell contains four CB5 molecules; those located around the inversion center at (1/2 1/2 1/2) display the same orientation, whereas the two others, related to the first by the binary axes (x 1/4 1/2) and (x 3/4 1/2), correspond to reversed, divergent orientations when viewed down c.

elements.content: Following the reporting of the first uranyl ion complexes with CB6, CB7, and CB8, the present work provides the first examples of complexes with CB5, which display novel features owing to the smaller size of the ligand. While the largest CBs complex the uranyl ion in an “external” fashion, with only one carbonyl group bound to each cation, the size of CB5 is perfectly adapted to “internal” uranyl complexation, with the cation bound to the five donors and perpendicular to the portal plane. This is what is observed in the open molecular capsule present in compound 1, in which one portal encompasses one uranyl ion while the other is free. In this case, as in other uranyl-containing cages and metallacycles, and notwithstanding the absence of a guest in the experimental conditions used, the uranyl oxo group directed toward the CB cavity can be considered as a potential binding site for Lewis acids or hydrogen bond donors. This complex presents a striking likeness with the open capsule built from CB5 and CdCl2, in which the nearly linear CdCl2 unit is also located along the main CB axis; it is also reminiscent of the uranyl complex with p-tert-butylcalix[5]arene, another macrocycle of comparable size. Another open capsule, described as a “metal-ion-bottomed molecular bowl” has also been formed from CB6 and cesium, in which the latter is viewed as a Lewis acid site with potential for substrate activation and chemical catalysis; the peculiar nature of the uranyl ion allows for an analogous compound with a Lewis base site. When alkali metal salts are added, heterometallic closed capsules are obtained, capped on one side by a uranyl ion and on the other by a potassium (2) or a cesium cation (3). Finally, in the extra presence of formic acid, the uranyl ion is separated from CB5 and capsules closed by K+ (4) or Cs+ (5) on both sides are formed with, in the former case, the presence of an included, disordered water molecule bound to the cation. These molecules are analogous to the discrete molecular containers previously described, in which CBs are capped by alkali, alkaline-earth, or lanthanide ions. These capsules are, however, not isolated in 4 and 5, but bound through the cations to a uranyl/formate/hydroxide two-dimensional framework, resulting in three-dimensional assemblages with alternate layers of uranyl-organic polymer and CB5 complexes. There is some analogy between these arrangements and that observed in a mixed uranyl/copper metal-organic framework, in which uranyl citrate dimers are incorporated in the interlayer spaces of a copper(II)/4,4′-bipyridine square grid assemblage (with, however, no coordination bonds connecting the two subunits in this case). Like the previous uranyl complexes with CBs, the present series thus show that both molecular species and uranyl-organic frameworks (UOFs) can be obtained, the latter when extra ligands readily giving polynuclear uranyl complexes or polymers are added (sulfate ions in the previous work, formate in the present cases). This opens a wide scope for research of novel compounds with original architectures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Following the reporting of the first uranyl ion complexes with CB6, CB7, and CB8, the present work provides the first examples of complexes with CB5, which display novel features owing to the smaller size of the ligand. While the largest CBs complex the uranyl ion in an "external" fashion, with only one carbonyl group bound to each cation, the size of CB5 is perfectly adapted to "internal" uranyl complexation, with the cation bound to the five donors and perpendicular to the portal plane. This is what is observed in the open molecular capsule present in compound 1, in which one portal encompasses one uranyl ion while the other is free. In this case, as in other uranyl-containing cages and metallacycles, and notwithstanding the absence of a guest in the experimental conditions used, the uranyl oxo group directed toward the CB cavity can be considered as a potential binding site for Lewis acids or hydrogen bond donors. This complex presents a striking likeness with the open capsule built from CB5 and CdCl2, in which the nearly linear CdCl2 unit is also located along the main CB axis; it is also reminiscent of the uranyl complex with p-tert-butylcalix[5]arene, another macrocycle of comparable size. Another open capsule, described as a "metal-ion-bottomed molecular bowl" has also been formed from CB6 and cesium, in which the latter is viewed as a Lewis acid site with potential for substrate activation and chemical catalysis; the peculiar nature of the uranyl ion allows for an analogous compound with a Lewis base site. When alkali metal salts are added, heterometallic closed capsules are obtained, capped on one side by a uranyl ion and on the other by a potassium (2) or a cesium cation (3). Finally, in the extra presence of formic acid, the uranyl ion is separated from CB5 and capsules closed by K+ (4) or Cs+ (5) on both sides are formed with, in the former case, the presence of an included, disordered water molecule bound to the cation. These molecules are analogous to the discrete molecular containers previously described, in which CBs are capped by alkali, alkaline-earth, or lanthanide ions. These capsules are, however, not isolated in 4 and 5, but bound through the cations to a uranyl/formate/hydroxide two-dimensional framework, resulting in three-dimensional assemblages with alternate layers of uranyl-organic polymer and CB5 complexes. There is some analogy between these arrangements and that observed in a mixed uranyl/copper metal-organic framework, in which uranyl citrate dimers are incorporated in the interlayer spaces of a copper(II)/4,4'-bipyridine square grid assemblage (with, however, no coordination bonds connecting the two subunits in this case). Like the previous uranyl complexes with CBs, the present series thus show that both molecular species and uranyl-organic frameworks (UOFs) can be obtained, the latter when extra ligands readily giving polynuclear uranyl complexes or polymers are added (sulfate ions in the previous work, formate in the present cases). This opens a wide scope for research of novel compounds with original architectures.

cln_elements.content:
CB5·12H2O (10 mg, 0.010 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO3 (29 mg, 0.101 mmol), excess HReO4 (100 mg, 0.398 mmol), and demineralized water (1.4 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 1 appeared within 2 days. The product was recovered after filtration and washed with water (8 mg, 49% yield based on CB5). Anal. Calcd for C30H34N20O22Re2U: C, 22.01; H, 2.09; N, 17.11. Found: C, 23.49; H, 2.81; N, 17.87%.

[UO<sub>2</sub>(CB5)K(NO<sub>3</sub>)][UO<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>4</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (2)

CB5·12H2O (10 mg, 0.010 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.100 mmol), KCl (8 mg, 0.107 mmol), and demineralized water (1.2 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 2 were obtained in low yield within 2 days.

{[UO<sub>2</sub>(CB5)Cs(NO<sub>3</sub>)]<sub>2</sub>[UO<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>4</sub>]}[UO<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>4</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (3)

CB5·12H2O (15 mg, 0.014 mmol), an 8-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (56 mg, 0.112 mmol), CsNO3 (14 mg, 0.072 mmol), and demineralized water (1.2 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 3 were obtained in low yield within 1 month.

[K<sub>2</sub>(CB5)(H<sub>2</sub>O)][(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(HCOO)(OH)<sub>4</sub>]<sub>2</sub>·6H<sub>2</sub>O (4)

CB5·12H2O (10 mg, 0.010 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO3 (29 mg, 0.101 mmol), KOH (6 mg, 0.107 mmol), formic acid (10 mg, 0.217 mmol), and demineralized water (1.2 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 4, mixed with a white powder which was not further characterized, were obtained in low yield within 2 days.

[Cs<sub>2</sub>(CB5)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>][(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(HCOO)(OH)<sub>4</sub>]<sub>2</sub>·3H<sub>2</sub>O (5)

CB5·12H2O (10 mg, 0.010 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO3 (29 mg, 0.101 mmol), CsOH (15 mg, 0.100 mmol), excess formic acid (28 mg, 0.609 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 5, mixed with a white powder which was not further characterized, were obtained in low yield within 3 days.

CB5⋅12H2O (10 mg, 0.010 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (50 mg, 0.100 mmol), KCl (8 mg, 0.107 mmol), and demineralized water (1.2 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 2 were obtained in low yield within 2 days.

{[UO2(CB5)Cs(NO3)]2[UO2(NO3)4]}[UO2(NO3)4]⋅2H2O (3)

CB5⋅12H2O (15 mg, 0.014 mmol), an 8-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (56 mg, 0.112 mmol), CsNO3 (14 mg, 0.072 mmol), and demineralized water (1.2 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 3 were obtained in low yield within 1 month.

[K2(CB5)(H2O)][(UO2)2(HCOO)(OH)4]2⋅6H2O (4)

CB5⋅12H2O (10 mg, 0.010 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO3 (29 mg, 0.101 mmol), KOH (6 mg, 0.107 mmol), formic acid (10 mg, 0.217 mmol), and demineralized water (1.2 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 4, mixed with a white powder which was not further characterized, were obtained in low yield within 2 days.

[Cs2(CB5)(H2O)2][(UO2)2(HCOO)(OH)4]2⋅3H2O (5)

CB5⋅12H2O (10 mg, 0.010 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO3 (29 mg, 0.101 mmol), CsOH (15 mg, 0.100 mmol), excess formic acid (28 mg, 0.609 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 5, mixed with a white powder which was not further characterized, were obtained in low yield within 3 days.
